I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Pakistan has requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance 
to  promote  industrial  environmental  improvement.    Technical  Assistance  (TA)  3944-PAK: 
Industrial Environmental Management1 for $700,000 was approved in July 2002.  ADB obtained 
co-financing of $1.0 million for Industrial Environmental Management Capacity Building from the 
Norwegian  Agency  for  Development  Cooperation  (NORAD).      A  TA  Fact-Finding  Mission2 
visited  Pakistan  during  13-17  April  2003  to  formulate  the  proposed  TA  and  reached  an 
understanding with the Government on the objective, scope, implementation arrangements, cost 
estimates, and terms of reference of consultants3.   The TA is included in the 2003 Country 
Strategy and Program Update. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The establishment of environmental policies and regulations in Pakistan began in 1975 
when the Environment and Urban Affairs Division (EUAD) was established in the Ministry of 
Housing  and  Works.  EUAD  was  instrumental  in  promulgating  the  landmark  Pakistan 
Environmental Protection Ordinance of 1983, which provided a legal framework for national 
environmental management and established the national environmental quality standards that 
set limits for emissions and discharges.  The Ordinance also called for the establishment of the 
Pakistan  Environmental  Protection  Agency  (Pak-EPA)  and  four  provincial  environmental 
protection agencies (provincial EPAs).  In 1994, the Government upgraded EUAD to the full-
fledged Ministry of Environment and Urban Affairs, headed by a minister.  In November 1996, it 
was redesignated as the Ministry of Environment, Local Government, and Rural Development 
(MELG&RD). The main function of MELG&RD is to ensure that environmental considerations 
and concerns of sustainable development are incorporated into national development plans and 
policies.  The Pakistan Environmental Protection Act (PEPA) was passed by Parliament on 11 
September 1997.  The Act empowers Pak-EPA to handle pollution-related problems as well as 
hazardous and toxic waste, and charges it and the provincial EPAs with implementing PEPA.  
Pak-EPA  is  a  department  of  MELG&RD.    The  federal  and  provincial  EPAs  have  similar 
organization structure.  A director general heads Pak-EPA and each provincial EPA and is 
assisted by directors, deputy directors, or assistant directors responsible for specific areas of 
environmental management.   
 
3.  The Government recognizes that promoting industrial environmental management is 
also  an  opportunity  to  improve  industrial  production  efficiency  through  cleaner  production.  
Cleaner production occurs when raw materials, water, energy, and other resources are utilized 
more efficiently, when less harmful substances are substituted for hazardous ones, and when 
toxic substances are eliminated from the production process. The result is less waste (or 
pollution)  at  the  end  of  the  production  process.    Through  this  approach,  environmental 
management does not have to be an added expense to the production process, but rather an 
opportunity to lower the per-unit cost of production.  Industrial environmental management is 
especially critical because, beginning on 1 January 2005, the World Trade Organization (WTO) 
will  require  all  countries  exporting  to  WTO’s  member  countries  to  meet  environmental 
guidelines.  Although this requirement will affect only the first-tier exporter in 2005, second- and 
third-tier4 suppliers will also be required to meet the WTO environmental requirements soon

4.  Other funding agencies have also been active in promoting industrial efficiency and 
environmental  management.    Currently,  both  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme 
(UNDP) and the United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO) have ongoing 
projects in this sector.  NORAD recently completed a project targeting waste reduction in the 
tanneries  sector  while  the  Netherlands  has  also  financed  a  project  to  promote  cleaner 
production in targeted industry sectors.  The International Union for Conservation of Nature and 
Natural Resources (IUCN) is implementing the Pakistan Environmental Program to strengthen 
the role of environmental nongovernment organizations (NGOs).  The Federation of Pakistan 
Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FPCCI) has an active program promoting improved 
industrial  environmental  management  among  the  members.    These  organizations  strongly 
welcome ADB’s timely assistance to the Government and support the undertaking of the TA.  
The TA is in line with ADB's Country Strategy and Program for Pakistan, which seeks to support 
sustainable growth and the private sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
5.  The TA will help the  Government promote industrial environmental management to 
improve industrial efficiency and competitiveness.  The objective will be achieved through the 
following ways:  (i) strengthen the institutional capacity and technical capability of Pak-EPA, 
provincial EPAs, and local governments and other organizations involved in promoting industrial 
environmental efficiency; (ii) develop environmental action plans for industries to establish a 
baseline  of  their  current  environmental  performance  and  set  benchmarks  for  future 
performance; (iii) train financial institutions to appraise investments for cleaner production and 
environmental management; and (iv) draft regulations and guidelines for implementing new 
market-based incentives and policies for industrial environmental management.  The TA is 
expected  to  strengthen  the  capability  of  Pak-EPA,  the  provincial  EPAs  and  relevant  local 
government agencies to develop and implement systems to improve and monitor industrial 
environmental management, and to improve the environmental performance of industries.  The 
TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The  TA  will  cover  the  four  provinces.    The  underlying  methodology  is  to  transfer 
international best practices on industrial efficiency and environmental management to Pakistan 
and build the capacity of government agencies as well as industry associations to serve as 
extension systems to promote adoption of best practices by industrial units.  The experience of 
industrial environmental management in Pakistan is that new initiatives started by aid agencies 
are forced to end when funding runs out.  To ensure the sustainability of this capacity building 
project,  the  TA  will  focus  on  adding  value  to  ongoing  Government  initiatives  by  providing 
catalytic interventions to build and strengthen these initiatives and ensure their effectiveness.  It 
is recognized that small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are the most difficult segment of 
industry to regulate and to prod improve their environmental performance. They are also the 
greatest polluters.  Therefore, the TA will emphasize this segment of industry.  The following are 
key activities of the TA.

3 
1.  Strengthen Capacity and Technical Capability of Pak-EPA, Provincial EPAs, 
and Industry 
 
7.  This component will have three parts: 
 
a.  Support the National Environmental Action Plan 
 
8.  The Government has started a national environmental action plan (NEAP) that will take 
immediate steps to achieve a visible improvement in the rapidly deteriorating environment 
through effective cooperation between government agencies and civil society. The NEAP, which 
will be implemented by MELG&RD will address four core areas:  (i) clean air, (ii) clean water, 
(iii)  solid  waste  management,  and  (iv)  ecosystem  management.    The  NEAP  has  six 
subprograms:  (i) policy coordination, (ii) pollution control, (iii) ecosystem management and 
natural  resource  conservation,  (iv)  energy  conservation  and  renewables,  (v)  dry  land 
management and water conservation, and (vi) support for grassroots initiatives.  The proposed 
TA specifically supports the pollution control subprogram. 
 
9.  The TA will help Pak-EPA and the provincial EPAs identify 6-8 priority industry sectors 
(e.g.,  tanneries,  textiles,  food  processing,  chemicals,  metal  finishing/fabrication,  cement, 
iron/steel, etc.) and help industry develop sector-specific environmental action plans (EAPs) for 
improving  industrial  environmental  management.    In  developing  the  EAPs,  Pak-EPA  and 
provincial EPAs will work with industry associations and NGOs to ensure strong stakeholder 
participation and ownership.  This effort will comprise three parts and will involve the following.  
(i) Review the needs assessment carried out by the Industrial Environmental Management TA to 
understand the needs of Pak-EPA and the provincial EPAs.  When the review is completed, the 
TA consultants will develop a detailed work plan for capacity building. (ii) Develop a sequenced 
training program for Pak-EPA,the provincial EPAs, other concerned government agencies and 
industry. To be implemented over 2 years, the program will include introductory as well as 
advanced training in designing approaches for promoting environmental management systems 
(EMS),  designing  initiatives,  technical  issues  concerning  EMS,  cleaner  production,  market-
based incentives, working with stakeholders, etc. (iii) Train Pak-EPA and provincial EPA staff to 
help industry associations develop and implement sector-specific Environmental Action Plan 
(EAPs). 
 
10.  The  TA  will  strengthen  the  capability  of  Pak-EPA,  the  provincial  EPAs,  and  local 
governments to develop, monitor, and implement sector-specific EAPs and 5-7 sectors specific 
EAPs that will serve as a basis for improving the environmental performance of industries.  The 
Government also envisions developing a program under which these EAPs will serve as a 
contract between industry and the Government to improve the environmental performance of 
industry over time. 
 
b.  Institutionalize the Self-Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) and the 
Environmental Management Information System (EMIS) 
 
11.  Pak-EPA, in consultation with industry, has developed a modeling system that industry 
can use to monitor its environmental performance.  In collaboration with the provincial EPAs and 
the FPCCI — the apex industry association representing sector-specific industry associations — 
Pak-EPA has piloted SMART with 50 industry units.  As a result of the pilot, Pak-EPA has 
received  applications  from  almost  300  additional  units  to  implement  SMART.  The  TA  will 
strengthen SMART by providing technical assistance and training to Pak-EPA, the provincial 
EPAs, concerned local government agencies, FPCCI, and participating industry associations to

4 
launch and implement SMART throughout Pakistan.  In addition, Pak-EPA has developed EMIS 
as a database of success stories and best practices on environmental management in Pakistan.  
The TA will help further populate the database with success stories and provide access to 
industry associations and industrial units via the internet.  The SMART modeling system will 
also feed into the EMIS database so that Pak-EPA and the provincial EPAs can record and 
monitor the performance of the industrial units. 
 
c.  Increase  Understanding  of  the  Value  of  Improved  Environmental 
Management 
 
12.  Tied to both parts will be awareness-raising activities for both industry and communities 
around the selected industries to help them understand the value of improved environmental 
management and play their respective roles in ensuring such improvement.  Much of this 
program will be based on promoting global best practices in corporate social responsibility and 
the interrelationship of the roles of industry, the government, and communities.  Part of this 
awareness-raising program will be to socially market SMART to industry as well as the public at 
large.  The recognition program will designate participating firms as “SMART companies” and 
will afford them recognition as socially responsible companies.  
 
2.  Assist  Financial  Institutions  in  Appraising  Loans  For  Cleaner  Production  and 
Environmental Management 
 
13.  Financial institutions have currently little or no capacity to understand, let alone appraise, 
loans for cleaner production and environmental management investments.  The TA will train 
appropriate  personnel  in  selected  financial  institutions  to  appraise  cleaner  production  and 
environmental management investments.  Special attention will be paid to financial institutions 
that are working with SMEs or have lines of credit from ADB to provide financing to SMEs. In 
addition, the TA will also train the Central Board of Revenue5 to build its understanding of and 
capacity for cleaner production and environmental management. 
 
3.  Assist Pak-EPA in Formulating Policies and Regulations 
 
14.  One  component  of  the  Industrial  Environmental  Management  TA6  will  formulate  a 
program of policy reform for industrial efficiency and environmental management and outline a 
policy framework matrix and action plan that will be implemented by the Government.  The TA 
will  help  Pak-EPA  draft  the  regulations  and  guidelines  for  implementing  the  policies 
recommended under TA  3944. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $1.25 million equivalent, comprising 
about $500,000 in foreign exchange and about $750,000 equivalent in local currency. The cost 
estimates are presented in Appendix 2.  ADB will provide $1.00 million, comprising $500,000 in 
foreign exchange and $500,000 equivalent of local currency.  The TA will be financed on a grant

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will use the project management unit (PMU) and steering committee, - with 
corresponding responsibilities, - that were formed for TA 3944.  Under the arrangements, Pak-
EPA will be the Executing Agency.  A PMU within Pak-EPA, headed by the director general, will 
be the focal point of the TA and will be responsible for daily supervision of the consulting team.  
The  consultants  and  the  PMU  will  hold  biweekly  progress  review  meetings  to  ensure 
coordination and smooth project implementation. 
 
17.  Local government entities will be included in the TA as the Government’s ongoing efforts 
at decentralization have the local government entities playing an ever increasing and critical role 
in industrial environmental management. 
 
18.  A high-level steering committee will be constituted to optimize effective participation, 
coordination, and implementation of the TA among the relevant federal, provincial, and local 
agencies, FPCCI, and other stakeholders. In recognition of the important role of FPCCI in this 
TA, FPCCI may organize working groups within its own structure that will include the relevant 
industry  subsectors.    The  secretary  of  MELG&RD  will  be  the  chairperson  of  the  steering 
committee.  The steering committee will be responsible for inter-agency coordination, provide 
the strategic direction for the proposed TA, review and approve the draft reports of the TA.   
 
19.  The TA will start in February 2004 with completion by February 2006. It will be carried 
out over 24 months by international consulting firms/institutes in association with domestic 
consultants. The total input of international and domestic consulting services will be about 24 
and 60 person-months, respectively. The consultants will have demonstrated experience in 
industrial environmental capacity building. The outline terms of reference for consulting services 
are in Appendix 3.  ADB will use simplified technical proposals and quality- and cost-based 
selection methods for selecting the consultants.  Consultants will be selected in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for 
engaging domestic consultants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Pakistan to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Norway for 
Industrial Environmental Management Capacity Building, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
1.   International Consultants 
 
1.  The TA will require 24 person-months of international consulting services. 
 
a.  Environmental  Capacity  Building  Specialist/Team  Leader  (12 
person-months) An international consultant or domestic consultant with international 
experience,  significant  and  demonstrable  experience  working  on  industrial 
environmental  issues  in  Pakistan,  and  demonstrated  experience  in  leading  a 
multicultural and multidisciplinary team will act as team leader. The consultant will take 
the lead in the following tasks and involve other consultant team members as necessary. 
(i)  Review  the  needs  assessment  carried  out  by  TA  3944-PAK:  Industrial 
Environmental Management consultants to familiarize themselves with the needs 
of  Pakistan  Environmental  Protection  Agency  (Pak-EPA)  and  the  provincial 
EPAs.  Upon completion of the review, the consultants will develop a detailed 
work plan, based on the terms of reference, and submit it to Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (NORAD), and 
the  project steering  committee  for  review  and  comments.    This  task  will be 
completed 1 month after project initiation.  The consultants will organize an 
inception tripartite meeting 2 weeks after the draft work plan is circulated to 
review  and  discuss  it.    The  consultant  will  include  the  findings  and 
recommendations of the tripartite meeting in the final work plan, to be submitted 
2 weeks after the meeting. 
 
(ii)  Develop a sequenced training program for Pak-EPA and the provincial EPAs as 
part of national environmental action plan (NEAP).  This program sequence to be 
implemented over 2 years, may include but will not be limited to (a) basics of 
environmental management systems (EMS) for industry; (b) EMS for small and 
medium enterprises (SMEs); (c) advanced EMS, including the ISO 14000 series, 
market-based  incentives  to  promote  EMS,  and  the  use  of  other  innovative 
approaches, and principles of cleaner production; (d) beyond EMS and cleaner 
production  (CP)  to  industrial  eco-efficiency;  (e)  establishing  environmental 
performance  indicators  (EPIs);  (f)  developing  an  environmental  management 
action  plan  involving  whole  industry  sectors,  factory  clusters,  and  individual 
facilities and including realistic targets, quantifiable indicators, and monitoring; 
and (g) developing and using EPIs for benchmarking, including identifying and 
evaluating international, regional, and national benchmarks. 
 
(iii)  Develop a training-of-trainers program and work with Pak-EPA, provincial EPAs, 
and industry associations to identify officials that will be designated as trainers in 
future training programs.   
 
(iv)  Review all current initiatives and tools available to Pak-EPA and the provincial 
EPAs  relevant  to  developing,  implementing,  and  monitoring  industry  sector 
environmental management actions plans and identify ways to improve them and

environmental  management  information  system  (EMIS),  self-monitoring  and 
reporting tool (SMART), and other initiatives, programs, or tools as necessary. 
 
(v)  Develop and implement an awareness-raising program for both industries and 
communities, using international best practices on corporate social responsibility.  
Part of the program will be designing and implementing a recognition program for 
industries implementing SMART.   
 
(vi)  Ensure  that  in  developing  the  above  programs,  the  approach  is  targeted  to 
SMEs. 
 
b.  Financial  Sector  Specialist  (4  person-months)  The  consultant  will  have 
experience in working with the financial sector in appraising cleaner production and 
industrial environmental management investments.  The consultant will take the lead in 
these tasks.

taking into account international best practices as well as local conditions. Pay 
special attention to financial institutions that are working with SMEs or have lines

c.  International Regulatory Specialist/Lawyer (8 person-months) The consultant 
will  have  experience  as  a  regulatory  specialist,  a  law  background,  or  significant 
demonstrated experience (at least 10 years) in drafting regulations and guidelines for 
industrial environmental management.  The consultant will take the lead in the following 
tasks. 
 
(i)  Review the program of policy reform for industrial efficiency and environmental 
management, policy framework matrix, and action plan that will be drafted under 
the Industrial Environmental Management TA. 
 
(ii)  Assist Pak-EPA in all stages of drafting regulations and guidelines.

2.  Domestic  Consultants  The  TA  will  require  60  person-months  of  domestic 
consulting services. 
a.  Industry Sector Specialists (44 person-months)1 It is expected that 6-8 industry 
sectors will be selected for technical assistance in preparing the NEAPs.  The specialists 
will be domestic consultants with significant experience in their specialty sector.  They 
will take the lead in working with the industry associations in their sector to establish 
international, regional, and national benchmarks for environmental best practices to 
serve  as  objectives  for  the  sector  NEAP.    Based  on  the  benchmarks,  the  sector 
specialists will work with the industry association to develop an action plan for the sector 
and work with individual industrial units to achieve the objectives.  The TA is expected to 
initially bring on six industry sector specialists   
 
b.  Domestic Regulatory Specialist (4 person-months) The specialist will have 
significant experience in industrial environmental regulations.  The specialist will help the 
international regulatory specialist understand the regulatory environment in Pakistan. 
 
c.  Information Technology Specialist (5 person-months) The specialist will have 
significant experience in developing and maintaining databases as well as in offering 
technical training.  The specialist will take the lead in any necessary upgrades to SMART 
and EMIS and provide technical training for the Pak-EPA and Pakistan Environmental 
Protection Act (PEPA) officers in charge of maintaining these databases. 
 
d.  Communication and Outreach Specialist (7 person-months) The specialist will 
have  demonstrated  experience  in  developing  a  communications  strategy  and 
implementing it through various forms of media.  The specialist will assist the team 
leader in developing and implementing the awareness-raising programs. 
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
Working with the other team members, the team leader will be responsible for the 
following reports: (i) an inception report to be submitted 1 month after project start-up; (ii) a 
quarterly progress report; (iii) a report for each task as outlined in the Scope of Work; and (iv) a 
midterm report at the completion of the first year, and a final report at the completion of the 
project.   
 
All major draft reports will be circulated to the steering committee, ADB, NORAD, and 
other stakeholders, under the cover of Pak-EPA for review and comment.  The consultants will
